elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Two new water soluble trinuclear copper(II) complexes, [Na6(H3O)4][Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)3]4(ClO4)6⋅3H2O (1) and [K(H2O)2][Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)]⋅3.75H2O (2) have been prepared via the reaction of an unsymmetrical amino dicarboxylic ligand, N-(2-carboxybenzomethyl)-β-alanine (H2cbal), Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O and NaOH/K2CO3, and characterized. The X-ray crystal structure analyses reveal that the three copper centers are at the corners of an equilateral triangle in complex 1, whereas in complex 2, the three copper centers are at the corners of a scalene triangle. Both the two complexes are investigated for their binding affinity with CT-DNA in aqueous solution at physiological pH using a combined approach of UV-Vis and fluorescence spectroscopic techniques.

While the X-ray crystal structure of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> reveals that the three copper(II) ions are in a distorted octahedral geometry forming an equilateral triangle, complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows that one copper(II) ion is in a distorted square pyramidal geometry, the other copper(II) ions are in a distorted trigonal bipyramidal and a distorted octahedral geometry forming a scalene triangle. elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two new water soluble trinuclear copper(II) complexes, [Na6(H3O)4][Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)3]4(ClO4)6⋅3H2O (1) and [K(H2O)2][Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)]⋅3.75H2O (2) have been synthesized in good yield via the reaction of an unsymmetrical amino dicarboxylic ligand, N-(2-carboxybenzomethyl)-β-alanine (H2cbal), Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O and NaOH/K2CO3 in methanol at room temperature. Complexes 1 and 2 have been characterized by elemental analysis, room temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements, FTIR, UV-Vis, mass spectrometry and single crystal X-ray crystallography. Both complexes contain a partial cubane [Cu3O4] core consisting of the trinuclear [{Cu(cbal)}3(μ3-OH)(H2O)3]- and [{Cu(cbal)}3(μ3-OH)(H2O)]- unit, respectively. While the X-ray crystal structure of complex 1 reveals that the three copper(II) ions are in a distorted octahedral geometry forming an equilateral triangle, complex 2 shows that one copper(II) ion is in a distorted square pyramidal geometry, the other copper(II) ions are in a distorted trigonal bipyramidal and a distorted octahedral geometry forming a scalene triangle. Complexes 1 and 2 are investigated for their binding affinity towards CT-DNA in aqueous medium at pH~7.5 using UV-Vis and fluorescence spectroscopic techniques. DFT calculation has been performed to calculate the Fukui functions at the metal sites as well as HOMOs and LUMOs in complexes 1 and 2 to elucidate the possible binding site with the DNA.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st020">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Nature has constructed numerous polynuclear copper complexes that perform an extraordinary array of catalytic transformations based on the cooperative interactions observed in biological systems . In recent years, considerable attention has been devoted to the polynuclear metal complexes due to their implications in catalysis, magnetism and biology. In this context, investigation of trinuclear copper(II) complexes should not only assist in the development of new low molecular weight catalysts and magnetic materials but could also shed light to biological processes that involve copper biomolecules . Within the scope of such applications, experimental and theoretical investigations of simple trinuclear copper(II) complexes have turned out to be a promising route to the understanding of various biological functions . Furthermore, the magnetic properties of such complexes reported in literature have indicated that the trinuclear complexes containing the [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O] core are a simple three-electron spin system. The three unpaired electrons in this core magnetically interact through super exchange involving Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>–O–Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> pathways resulting in the antiferro- or ferromagnetic complexes. Hence, it is vital to synthesize the low molecular weight trinuclear copper(II) complexes with triangular arrangement of metal ions in order to study these properties.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Nature has constructed numerous polynuclear copper complexes that perform an extraordinary array of catalytic transformations based on the cooperative interactions observed in biological systems . In recent years, considerable attention has been devoted to the polynuclear metal complexes due to their implications in catalysis, magnetism and biology. In this context, investigation of trinuclear copper(II) complexes should not only assist in the development of new low molecular weight catalysts and magnetic materials but could also shed light to biological processes that involve copper biomolecules . Within the scope of such applications, experimental and theoretical investigations of simple trinuclear copper(II) complexes have turned out to be a promising route to the understanding of various biological functions . Furthermore, the magnetic properties of such complexes reported in literature have indicated that the trinuclear complexes containing the [Cu3O] core are a simple three-electron spin system. The three unpaired electrons in this core magnetically interact through super exchange involving CuII-O-CuII pathways resulting in the antiferro- or ferromagnetic complexes. Hence, it is vital to synthesize the low molecular weight trinuclear copper(II) complexes with triangular arrangement of metal ions in order to study these properties.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">The carboxylate-rich ligands have been used by us  as a way to bind the divalent Co(II), Cu(II) and Zn(II) metal ions to produce mono-, di-, tetra-, hexa-, and heptanuclear complexes under various reaction conditions. Several tridentate [O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N] or [ON<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] donor set ligands have readily afforded trinuclear copper(II) complexes with [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O] core . There are some mono- and dinuclear copper(II) complexes reported in the literature that promote binding and cleavage of biomolecules such as DNA and protein . Sorenson and Oberley investigated the anticancer potential of copper(II) complexes in animal models . The investigation reported that animals treated with the complexes showed several health benefits such as inhibiting tumor growth and metastasis slow-down, host organism survivability, and induction of morphological differentiation of cancerous cells . There are reports in the literature on multinuclear copper(II) complexes which can efficiently promote the binding and cleavage of biological macromolecules . However, the systematic and detailed study of such binding and cleavage of biological macromolecules has been sporadic, probably due to the unavailability of structurally characterized highly water soluble trinuclear copper(II) complexes . Very recently, we reported di-, tetra- and hexanuclear copper(II), zinc(II) and cobalt(II) complexes built upon dinucleating ligands and their binding interactions with various biological micro- and macromolecules in aqueous medium . While the study has established a strong interaction between the complexes and the biomolecules, none of the complexes had direct structural resemblance to any known metalloprotein. However, the complexes reported herein are structurally similar to the ferredoxins, [3Fe-4S] clusters widely found in nature. In this paper, thus, we report the synthesis, structure, spectroscopic characterization, and DNA binding affinity of two new water soluble μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-hydroxo bridged trinuclear copper(II) complexes containing partial cubane [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] cores. The contribution here is two folds: (a) a rational design in the synthesis of, otherwise difficult, cubane core water soluble metal complexes, and (b) the affinity of these partial cubane core complexes to DNA.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The carboxylate-rich ligands have been used by us  as a way to bind the divalent Co(II), Cu(II) and Zn(II) metal ions to produce mono-, di-, tetra-, hexa-, and heptanuclear complexes under various reaction conditions. Several tridentate [O2N] or [ON2] donor set ligands have readily afforded trinuclear copper(II) complexes with [Cu3O] core . There are some mono- and dinuclear copper(II) complexes reported in the literature that promote binding and cleavage of biomolecules such as DNA and protein . Sorenson and Oberley investigated the anticancer potential of copper(II) complexes in animal models . The investigation reported that animals treated with the complexes showed several health benefits such as inhibiting tumor growth and metastasis slow-down, host organism survivability, and induction of morphological differentiation of cancerous cells . There are reports in the literature on multinuclear copper(II) complexes which can efficiently promote the binding and cleavage of biological macromolecules . However, the systematic and detailed study of such binding and cleavage of biological macromolecules has been sporadic, probably due to the unavailability of structurally characterized highly water soluble trinuclear copper(II) complexes . Very recently, we reported di-, tetra- and hexanuclear copper(II), zinc(II) and cobalt(II) complexes built upon dinucleating ligands and their binding interactions with various biological micro- and macromolecules in aqueous medium . While the study has established a strong interaction between the complexes and the biomolecules, none of the complexes had direct structural resemblance to any known metalloprotein. However, the complexes reported herein are structurally similar to the ferredoxins, [3Fe-4S] clusters widely found in nature. In this paper, thus, we report the synthesis, structure, spectroscopic characterization, and DNA binding affinity of two new water soluble μ3-hydroxo bridged trinuclear copper(II) complexes containing partial cubane [Cu3O4] cores. The contribution here is two folds: (a) a rational design in the synthesis of, otherwise difficult, cubane core water soluble metal complexes, and (b) the affinity of these partial cubane core complexes to DNA.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st025">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st030">Materials</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">2-Carboxybenzaldehyde, β-alanine and sodium borohydride were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich Chemie GmbH, Germany. Hydrochloric acid and perchloric acid were purchased from Merck, India. Copper(II) perchlorate hexahydrate was prepared by treating copper(II) carbonate with 1:1 perchloric acid and crystallized after concentrating on water bath. Calf thymus DNA (CT-DNA) was purchased from SRL, India and stored at 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. All other chemicals and solvents were reagent grade materials and used as received from commercial sources without further purification.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials

2-Carboxybenzaldehyde, β-alanine and sodium borohydride were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Chemie GmbH, Germany. Hydrochloric acid and perchloric acid were purchased from Merck, India. Copper(II) perchlorate hexahydrate was prepared by treating copper(II) carbonate with 1:1 perchloric acid and crystallized after concentrating on water bath. Calf thymus DNA (CT-DNA) was purchased from SRL, India and stored at 4°C. All other chemicals and solvents were reagent grade materials and used as received from commercial sources without further purification.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st035">Physical measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Microanalyses (C,H,N) were carried out using a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHNS/O Series II elemental analyzer. FTIR spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer L120-000A spectrometer (200–4000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>). <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H and <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C NMR spectra were obtained in D<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O solution on a Bruker AC 400 NMR spectrometer. The room temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured using a home built Gouy balance fitted with a polytronic DC power supply. Diamagnetic corrections for ligand susceptibilities were made using Pascal’s constants. The ESI mass spectra were recorded using a Micromass Q-Tof Micro™ (Waters) mass spectrometer. UV–Vis spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu UV 1800 (190–1100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm quartz cell) spectrophotometer. Fluorescence spectra were obtained using a Perkin-Elmer LS55 Spectrofluorimeter equipped with FLWINLAB software with a rectangular quartz cuvette of path length 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Physical measurements

Microanalyses (C,H,N) were carried out using a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHNS/O Series II elemental analyzer. FTIR spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer L120-000A spectrometer (200-4000cm-1). 1H and 13C NMR spectra were obtained in D2O solution on a Bruker AC 400 NMR spectrometer. The room temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured using a home built Gouy balance fitted with a polytronic DC power supply. Diamagnetic corrections for ligand susceptibilities were made using Pascal's constants. The ESI mass spectra were recorded using a Micromass Q-Tof Micro™ (Waters) mass spectrometer. UV-Vis spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu UV 1800 (190-1100nm) (1cm quartz cell) spectrophotometer. Fluorescence spectra were obtained using a Perkin-Elmer LS55 Spectrofluorimeter equipped with FLWINLAB software with a rectangular quartz cuvette of path length 1cm.

Synthesis of N-(2-carboxybenzomethyl)-β-alanine, H2cbal

The ligand H2cbal was synthesized according to our previously published procedure . Yield: 8.5g (76%). Anal. Calcd. for C11H13NO4: C, 59.19; H, 5.87; N, 6.27. Found: C, 59.10; H, 5.92; N, 6.18%. FTIR (cm-1): ν =3427(b), 2967(b), 1698(s), 1597(s), 1454(s), 1392(s), 1340(s), 1242(s), 1175(s), 1057(s), 936(s), 837(s), 762(s), 718(s). 13C NMR for the sodium salt of the compound (100MHz, D2O, room temperature, δ): 180.03, 177.16, 138.97, 132.84, 130.48, 129.63, 128.26, 128.14, 50.57, 44.38, 35.55.

Synthesis of [Na6(H3O)4][Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)3]4(ClO4)6⋅3H2O (1)

A methanol (10ml) solution of Cu(ClO4)2 ⋅6H2O (0.415g, 1.12mmol) was added to a solution of H2cbal (0.250g, 1.12mmol) and NaOH (0.089g, 2.24mmol) in methanol (10ml) with magnetic stirring during a period of 15min. The reaction mixture was stirred for 1h resulting in a blue solution. The solution was filtered to discard any insoluble precipitate. The solvent was evaporated in air from the clear filtrate. The blue compound was isolated by filtration through a glass frit and washed with methanol and hexane and finally dried in vacuo over P4O10. Yield: 0.362g (85%). Anal. Calcd. for C132H172N12O92Cl6Na6Cu12 (1-3H2O): C, 35.14; H, 3.84; N, 3.73; Cu, 16.90. Found: C, 35.31; H, 3.67; N, 3.85; Cu, 16.75. FTIR (cm-1): ν =3422(b), 1607(s), 1593(s), 1569(s), 1451(s), 1372(s), 1202(s), 1140(s), 1087(s), 951(s), 897(s), 849(s), 764(s), 626(s). UV-Vis spectra: λ max (ε, lmol-1 cm-1) (H2O solution): 705 (231), 272 (7955), 228 (27523). Magnetic moment, μ eff (tot.): 2.97μB; μ eff/Cu: 1.72μB. Mass spectrum (ESI): m/z 877 (M - ={[Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-O)]+Li}-), 855 (M - ={[Cu3(cbal)3}-).

Synthesis of [K(H2O)2][Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)]⋅3.75H2O (2)

A methanol (10ml) solution of Cu(ClO4)2 ⋅6H2O (0.415g, 1.12mmol) was added to a solution of H2cbal (0.250g, 1.12mmol) and K2CO3 (0.309g, 2.24mmol) in methanol (10ml) with magnetic stirring during a period of 15min. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1h resulting in a blue solution. The solution was filtered to discard any insoluble precipitate. The solvent was evaporated in air from the clear filtrate. The blue compound was separated by filtration through a glass frit and washed with methanol and hexane and finally dried in vacuo over P4O10. Yield: 0.311g (90%). Anal. Calcd. for C33H40N3O16KCu3 (2-3.75H2O): C, 41.10; H, 4.18; N, 4.36; Cu, 19.77. Found: C, 41.35; H, 3.98; N, 4.57; Cu, 20.01. FTIR (KBr, cm-1): ν =3422(b), 1586(s), 1560(s), 1452(s), 1388(s), 1110(s), 1093(b), 947(s), 860(s), 763(s), 629(s). UV-Vis spectra: λ max (ε, lmol-1 cm-1) (H2O solution)=719 (86), 274 (2074), 225 (6771). Magnetic moment, μ eff (tot.): 2.94μB; μ eff/Cu: 1.70μB. Mass spectrum (ESI): m/z 927 (M - ={[Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-O)(H2O)(CH3OH)]+Li}-), 895 (M - ={[Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-O)(H2O)]+Li}-), 877 (M - ={[Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-O)]+Li}-), 855 (M - ={[Cu3(cbal)3}-).

elements.clean_text:
Caution

Perchlorate salts of metal complexes are potentially explosive and should be handled in small quantities with great care.

X-ray crystallographic study and data analysis

Blue needle shaped single crystals of complex 1 were obtained by slow ether diffusion into the methanol-water solution of the complex after ~10days. Similarly, the blue plate shaped single crystals of complex 2 were grown by slow ether diffusion into the methanol-water solution of the complex after ~15days. Crystal data as well as data collection and refinement for both complexes 1 and 2 are summarized in  . Selected bond distances and bond angles are given in  . Clear blue needle shaped single crystals of complex 1 with approximate dimensions of 0.35×0.27×0.11mm and blue plate shaped single crystals of complex 2 with approximate dimensions 0.34×0.20×0.04mm were selected for structural analysis. Intensity data for these compounds were collected using a diffractometer with a Bruker SMART CCD area detector  and graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). For 1, a total of 1802 data were measured with Miller indices h min =-16, h max =16, k min =-16, k max =16, l min =-19, l max =19, in the range 1.44< θ <21.63° using ω oscillation frames. The data were corrected for absorption by the multi-scan method  giving minimum and maximum transmission factors. For 2, a total of 7239 data were recorded with Miller indices h min =-21, h max =25, k min =-12, k max =7, l min =-20, l max =21, in the range 0.95< θ <25.00° using ω oscillation frames. The data were corrected for absorption by the multi-scan method  giving minimum and maximum transmission factors. The structures were solved by direct methods using the software SIR97 , and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 using the program shelxl  embedded in the routine  Olex2  . Moreover, 15 solvent water molecules are located over several positions in the unit cell of complex 2, which cannot be located precisely and have treated as a diffuse contribution to the overall scattering without specific atom positions by squeeze/platon . Hydrogen atom positions were initially determined by geometry and refined by a riding model. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. All hydrogen atoms were generated at ideal positions (C-H, 0.96Å), and fixed with isotropic thermal parameters.

<ce:section-title id="st060">DNA binding study</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Experiments involving the reaction/interaction of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with CT-DNA were carried out in aqueous solution in 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mM Tris–HCl buffer (pH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>∼<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7.5) maintaining a constant ionic strength with 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M NaCl. The experiments were run by titrating fixed concentration of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (1.06<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M) with varying concentration of CT-DNA (0–2.24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−5</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M). Concentrations of CT-DNA solutions were determined by absorption spectroscopy using the molar extinction coefficient 13,600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> at 260<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm . These DNA concentrations correspond to the base pairs. Purity of the CT-DNA was checked by monitoring the ratio of the absorbance at 260<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm to that at 280<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, which was in the range of 1.8–1.9. Optical Density (O.D.) was measured at 272 and 228<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, and 276 and 225<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively, using a Shimadzu UV 1800 UV–Visible Spectrophotometer (190–1100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) with a rectangular quartz cuvette of path length 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm. The absorbance of DNA itself was subtracted by adding an equal amount of DNA to both the complex solution and the reference solution. Again, In order to study the contribution of electrostatic interactions in the DNA binding with complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, UV–Vis titration experiments were conducted as described above but with an increase in the ionic strength of the reaction medium by the addition of NaCl from 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup> to 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M. DNA binding property was also studied using fluorescence spectroscopic technique. To execute fluorescence titration experiments, initially the CT-DNA was incubated with ethidium bromide (EthBr) ([EthBr]/[DNA]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.1) at 37<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in the dark environment for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min. Then the solution of DNA/EthBr mixture was titrated with varying concentrations of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> separately, from 0–6.20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M in 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mM Tris–HCl buffer (pH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>∼<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7.5) in aqueous medium upon excitation at 510<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm using a Perkin Elmer-LS55 Spectrofluorimeter equipped with FLWINLAB software with a rectangular quartz cuvette of path length 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm. The emission peak was observed at ∼598<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
DNA binding study

Experiments involving the reaction/interaction of complexes 1 and 2 with CT-DNA were carried out in aqueous solution in 30mM Tris-HCl buffer (pH~7.5) maintaining a constant ionic strength with 1×10-3 M NaCl. The experiments were run by titrating fixed concentration of complexes 1 and 2 (1.06×10-4 M) with varying concentration of CT-DNA (0-2.24×10-5 M). Concentrations of CT-DNA solutions were determined by absorption spectroscopy using the molar extinction coefficient 13,600M-1 cm-1 at 260nm . These DNA concentrations correspond to the base pairs. Purity of the CT-DNA was checked by monitoring the ratio of the absorbance at 260nm to that at 280nm, which was in the range of 1.8-1.9. Optical Density (O.D.) was measured at 272 and 228nm for complex 1, and 276 and 225nm for complex 2, respectively, using a Shimadzu UV 1800 UV-Visible Spectrophotometer (190-1100nm) with a rectangular quartz cuvette of path length 1cm. The absorbance of DNA itself was subtracted by adding an equal amount of DNA to both the complex solution and the reference solution. Again, In order to study the contribution of electrostatic interactions in the DNA binding with complexes 1 and 2, UV-Vis titration experiments were conducted as described above but with an increase in the ionic strength of the reaction medium by the addition of NaCl from 1×10-4 to 1×10-2 M. DNA binding property was also studied using fluorescence spectroscopic technique. To execute fluorescence titration experiments, initially the CT-DNA was incubated with ethidium bromide (EthBr) ([EthBr]/[DNA]=0.1) at 37°C in the dark environment for 30min. Then the solution of DNA/EthBr mixture was titrated with varying concentrations of complexes 1 and 2 separately, from 0-6.20×10-4 M in 30mM Tris-HCl buffer (pH~7.5) in aqueous medium upon excitation at 510nm using a Perkin Elmer-LS55 Spectrofluorimeter equipped with FLWINLAB software with a rectangular quartz cuvette of path length 1cm. The emission peak was observed at ~598nm.

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1) electron systems, where N is the total number of electrons in the system. In a finite difference approximation, <ce:italic>f</ce:italic>

elements.clean_text:
Theoretical calculations

Theoretical calculations regarding structure optimization, Fukui function (f k +) of the metal sites of complexes 1 and 2 were performed with the Gaussian 03 software . The functions (f k +) were evaluated from single point calculations using the B3LYP  method and 6-311G  basis set at the optimized geometry, performed for N and (N +1) electron systems, where N is the total number of electrons in the system. In a finite difference approximation, f k + of an atom k, in a molecule with N electrons, is expressed by the equation f k + =[qk (N)- qk (N +1)], where qk  is the charge of atom k . The qk  values were calculated by Mulliken population analysis (MPA).

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis and general characterizations

The unsymmetrical amino dicarboxylic ligand, H2cbal has been synthesized following our published procedure () . The ligand is fully characterized using analytical techniques such as elemental analysis, FTIR, 1H, and 13C NMR spectroscopy. The H2cbal ligand is known to coordinate with copper(II) ions to form a tetranuclear copper(II) complex that displayed a distinct mode of bridging carboxylate coordinations . Recently, we have reported zinc(II) mediated cyclization of H2cbal and its subsequent coordination under different reaction conditions .

elements.clean_text: The reaction of H2cbal with Cu(ClO4)2 ⋅6H2O and NaOH in 1:1:2 molar ratio in methanol at room temperature in air afforded a blue trinuclear copper(II) complex, [Na6(H3O)4][Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)3]4(ClO4)6⋅3H2O (1) ( ). Similarly, the reaction of H2cbal with Cu(ClO4)2 ⋅6H2O and K2CO3 in 1:1:2 molar ratio in methanol at ambient temperature in air yielded a blue trinuclear copper(II) complex, [K(H2O)2][Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)]⋅3.75H2O (2) (). The molecular structures of complexes 1 and 2 have been established using different analytical techniques such as elemental analysis, FTIR, UV-Vis, mass spectrometry and single crystal X-ray crystallography. The room temperature magnetic moment values per copper for complexes 1 and 2 are 1.72μB and 1.70μB, respectively, indicating the presence of one unpaired electron in each copper(II) ion.

The complex crystallizes in the hexagonal <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>6<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>m</ce:italic> space group with the refined formula [Na<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(cbal)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). In the unit cell four anionic [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(cbal)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> trinuclear units, six Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> and six ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> counter ions along with three water molecules of crystallization and additionally, to balance the total charge, four hydronium ions (formally O11 or O11B and O12) are present. The anionic cluster is constituted by three [Cu(cbal)] subunits in which each copper(II) ion is coordinated to a deprotonated tridentate ligand, cbal<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>. The [Cu(cbal)] subunits are held together by two distinct bridging systems: (i) one μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-hydroxo group (O5) which is coordinated to each of the three copper centers  and (ii) the three bridging aliphatic carboxylate oxygen atoms, each coming from different ligand unit. The resulting trinuclear species can be viewed as either a partial cubane or a cubane with one missing corner of the [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] core. In the trinuclear unit, the three copper(II) ions assemble at the corners of an equilateral triangle with ∼3.202(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å edges (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). Each copper(II) ion is in a Jahn–Teller distorted octahedral geometry with the bridging aliphatic carboxylate oxygen of the ligand and an exogenous H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecule occupying the elongated axial positions. While the square base of the octahedral geometry around each copper(II) center is defined by the O1, N1, O3′ and O5 atoms, the axial positions are taken by O3 and O10 atoms. The average Cu–O(bridging hydroxo) and Cu–O(bridging carboxylate) bond distances are 2.017 and 2.137<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. The Cu–O(hydroxo)–Cu and Cu–O(carboxylate)–Cu bridging angles are 105.1(2)° and 96.77(18)°, respectively. The μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-O5 atom is located at 0.807<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å above the plane defined by the three copper(II) ions. This induces a relatively bigger Cu–O(hydroxo)–Cu bridging bond angle of 105.1(2)° on the structure when compared to the smaller Cu–O(carboxylate)–Cu bridging angle of 96.77(18)°. The observed Cu-<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>-<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>-Cu inter-metallic distance at 3.202(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å in the complex is comparable to the values reported in the literature . The crystal structure of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> features several modes of carboxylate binding involved in a 3D coordination network in which the trinuclear Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> units are inter-linked through the Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ions (). The plentiful hydrogen bonding interactions among the coordinated water molecules and carboxylate oxygen atoms of the ligand contribute towards the stabilization of the crystal lattice.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Description of X-ray crystal structure of complex 1 

A structural view of the trinuclear unit of complex 1 with the atom numbering scheme is shown in  . The complex crystallizes in the hexagonal P63/m space group with the refined formula [Na6(H3O)4][Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)3]4(ClO4)6⋅3H2O (1). In the unit cell four anionic [Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)3]- trinuclear units, six Na+ and six ClO4 - counter ions along with three water molecules of crystallization and additionally, to balance the total charge, four hydronium ions (formally O11 or O11B and O12) are present. The anionic cluster is constituted by three [Cu(cbal)] subunits in which each copper(II) ion is coordinated to a deprotonated tridentate ligand, cbal2-. The [Cu(cbal)] subunits are held together by two distinct bridging systems: (i) one μ3-hydroxo group (O5) which is coordinated to each of the three copper centers  and (ii) the three bridging aliphatic carboxylate oxygen atoms, each coming from different ligand unit. The resulting trinuclear species can be viewed as either a partial cubane or a cubane with one missing corner of the [Cu3O4] core. In the trinuclear unit, the three copper(II) ions assemble at the corners of an equilateral triangle with ~3.202(2)Å edges ( ). Each copper(II) ion is in a Jahn-Teller distorted octahedral geometry with the bridging aliphatic carboxylate oxygen of the ligand and an exogenous H2O molecule occupying the elongated axial positions. While the square base of the octahedral geometry around each copper(II) center is defined by the O1, N1, O3' and O5 atoms, the axial positions are taken by O3 and O10 atoms. The average Cu-O(bridging hydroxo) and Cu-O(bridging carboxylate) bond distances are 2.017 and 2.137Å, respectively. The Cu-O(hydroxo)-Cu and Cu-O(carboxylate)-Cu bridging angles are 105.1(2)° and 96.77(18)°, respectively. The μ3-O5 atom is located at 0.807Å above the plane defined by the three copper(II) ions. This induces a relatively bigger Cu-O(hydroxo)-Cu bridging bond angle of 105.1(2)° on the structure when compared to the smaller Cu-O(carboxylate)-Cu bridging angle of 96.77(18)°. The observed Cu---Cu inter-metallic distance at 3.202(2)Å in the complex is comparable to the values reported in the literature . The crystal structure of complex 1 features several modes of carboxylate binding involved in a 3D coordination network in which the trinuclear Cu3 units are inter-linked through the Na+ ions (). The plentiful hydrogen bonding interactions among the coordinated water molecules and carboxylate oxygen atoms of the ligand contribute towards the stabilization of the crystal lattice.

</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">A structural view of the trinuclear body of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with the atom numbering scheme is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>. The complex crystallizes in the monoclinic <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> space group with the refined formula [K(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(cbal)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·3.75H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. Unlike to complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, each metal center of the Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> unit poses different coordination geometries. The coordination geometry around the Cu1, Cu2 and Cu3 centers is best described as distorted octahedral, square pyramidal and trigonal bipyramidal geometry, respectively. While the square base of the octahedral geometry around the Cu1 center is defined by the O1, O14, O3 and N1 atoms, the axial positions are occupied by the O11 and O13 atoms. The square base of the square pyramidal geometry around the Cu2 center is described by the O5, O14, O7 and N2 atoms, whereas the axial position is occupied by the O3 atom. The trigonal bipyramidal geometry around Cu3 center is defined by the O5, O11 and O7 atoms at the equatorial position, and N3 and O14 atoms at the axial position. The coordination environment of the counter cation K<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> is best described by the distorted octahedral geometry, with four carboxylate and two water oxygens. The Cu1–O11 bond distance of 2.377(7)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å is slightly longer when compared to the 2.217(6) and 2.233(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å values for Cu2–O3 and Cu3–O7, respectively. The Cu–O(bridging carboxylate)–Cu bond angles are 97.6(2)°, 96.5(3)° and 94.2(3)° for Cu1–O3–Cu2, Cu2–O7–Cu3 and Cu3–O11–Cu1, respectively. The Cu1–O14 and Cu2–O14 bond length values between the copper(II) ions and the central μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH oxygen atom are almost identical at 2.069(6) and 2.002(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively, while the Cu3–O14 distance is 1.966(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-O14 atom is located at 0.842<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å above the plane defined by the three copper(II) ions. This opens the Cu–O<ce:inf loc="post">hydroxo</ce:inf>–Cu bond angle to an average value of 103.69°. Unlike to complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> triangle in complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is not equilateral as the Cu-<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>-<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>-Cu edges are at 3.115(2), 3.174(3) and 3.204(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å distances (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). Again, the average Cu-<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>-<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>-Cu separation of 3.164<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å is comparable to the values reported in the literature for similar complexes . Similar to complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the crystal structure of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> displays a 3D coordination network in which the trinuclear Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> units are connected to each other through K<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ions (). The complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> also shows an intricate hydrogen bonding among the coordinated water molecule, secondary amine and carboxylate groups of the ligand, contributing to the stabilization of the crystal structure.</ce:para>

Description of X-ray crystal structure of complex 2 

A structural view of the trinuclear body of complex 2 with the atom numbering scheme is shown in  . The complex crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/c space group with the refined formula [K(H2O)2][Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)]⋅3.75H2O. Unlike to complex 1, each metal center of the Cu3 unit poses different coordination geometries. The coordination geometry around the Cu1, Cu2 and Cu3 centers is best described as distorted octahedral, square pyramidal and trigonal bipyramidal geometry, respectively. While the square base of the octahedral geometry around the Cu1 center is defined by the O1, O14, O3 and N1 atoms, the axial positions are occupied by the O11 and O13 atoms. The square base of the square pyramidal geometry around the Cu2 center is described by the O5, O14, O7 and N2 atoms, whereas the axial position is occupied by the O3 atom. The trigonal bipyramidal geometry around Cu3 center is defined by the O5, O11 and O7 atoms at the equatorial position, and N3 and O14 atoms at the axial position. The coordination environment of the counter cation K+ is best described by the distorted octahedral geometry, with four carboxylate and two water oxygens. The Cu1-O11 bond distance of 2.377(7)Å is slightly longer when compared to the 2.217(6) and 2.233(6)Å values for Cu2-O3 and Cu3-O7, respectively. The Cu-O(bridging carboxylate)-Cu bond angles are 97.6(2)°, 96.5(3)° and 94.2(3)° for Cu1-O3-Cu2, Cu2-O7-Cu3 and Cu3-O11-Cu1, respectively. The Cu1-O14 and Cu2-O14 bond length values between the copper(II) ions and the central μ3-OH oxygen atom are almost identical at 2.069(6) and 2.002(6)Å, respectively, while the Cu3-O14 distance is 1.966(6)Å. The μ3-O14 atom is located at 0.842Å above the plane defined by the three copper(II) ions. This opens the Cu-Ohydroxo-Cu bond angle to an average value of 103.69°. Unlike to complex 1, the Cu3 triangle in complex 2 is not equilateral as the Cu---Cu edges are at 3.115(2), 3.174(3) and 3.204(3)Å distances ( ). Again, the average Cu---Cu separation of 3.164Å is comparable to the values reported in the literature for similar complexes . Similar to complex 1, the crystal structure of complex 2 displays a 3D coordination network in which the trinuclear Cu3 units are connected to each other through K+ ions (). The complex 2 also shows an intricate hydrogen bonding among the coordinated water molecule, secondary amine and carboxylate groups of the ligand, contributing to the stabilization of the crystal structure.

elements.clean_text:
Solution UV-Vis and MS studies

The solution behavior of complexes 1 and 2 was analyzed using UV-Vis and mass spectrometric techniques. UV-Vis spectra were obtained on aqueous solutions (pH~7.5) of the complexes. The spectrum of complex 1 displays a broad absorption band at 705nm (ε, 231lmol-1 cm-1) due to the d-d transition. The spectrum also shows two distinct metal ion bound ligand-based π→π∗ transitions at 272nm (ε, 7955lmol-1 cm-1) and 228nm (ε, 27523lmol-1 cm-1). Similarly, the spectrum of complex 2 shows a broad absorption band at 719nm (ε, 86lmol-1 cm-1) due to the d-d transition. The spectrum also indicates two distinct metal ion bound ligand-based π→π∗ transitions at 274nm (ε, 2074lmol-1 cm-1) and 225nm (ε, 6771lmol-1 cm-1). No significant changes were observed in UV-Vis spectra when complexes 1 and 2 were measured in aqueous solutions (pH~7.5) after ~24h. The representative UV-Vis spectra for complex 1 are shown in the . Indeed, the solution stability of the cluster species has been authenticated previously using the spectrophotometric method . Thus, the stability of complexes in solution is established.

elements.clean_text: In an attempt to study the stability of the complexes under the experimental conditions, the electrospray ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) were carried out. In a typical experiment, aqueous solutions of the complexes at pH~7.5 were subjected to ESI mass spectrometric analysis in negative-ion mode using a quadrupole ion-trap mass spectrometer. The mass spectrum of complex 1 () contains the molecular ion peaks at m/z =877 and 855 which correspond to {[Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-O)]+Li}- and {[Cu3(cbal)3}- species, respectively. Similarly, the mass spectrum of complex 2 () displays the molecular ion peaks at m/z =927, 895, 877 and 855 that correspond to {[Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-O)(H2O)(CH3OH)]+Li}-, {[Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-O)(H2O)]+Li}-, [Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-O)]+Li}- and {[Cu3(cbal)3}- species, respectively. Hence, the ESI mass spectrometric studies corroborate the UV-Vis results that the trinuclear complexes 1 and 2 are stable in solution at physiological pH.

elements.clean_text:
DNA binding study

The trinuclear complexes 1 and 2 are highly water soluble and well stable in solution at physiological pH. Therefore, considering the important role and activity of copper ion and its complexes in the biological systems that they may act as biological probes, we were interested to study their DNA binding affinity in aqueous medium. The binding characteristics of complexes 1 and 2 with calf-thymus (CT) DNA have been examined by a combined approach of UV-Vis and fluorescence spectroscopic techniques. The binding with DNA leads to a gradual increase in the absorption intensities in the UV-Vis spectra of complexes 1 and 2 accompanied by a significant blue shift. The observed UV-Vis spectroscopic results suggest that the complex/DNA assembly via covalent and/or non-covalent interactions  is expected to perturb the ligand based electronic transitions of the complexes. The UV-Vis spectra obtained during the titration of complex 1 in the presence of increasing concentration of CT-DNA are given in  . The UV-Vis spectra clearly show significant hyperchromism in both the charge transfer regions with a blue shift of 2-5nm of the absorption maximum of complex 1 (λ max(1)=228nm, 272nm) upon CT-DNA binding (λ max =226nm, 267nm, ). Similarly, the UV-Vis spectra indicate a blue-shift of 3-6nm of the absorption maximum of complex 2 (λ max(2)=225nm, 274nm) upon CT-DNA binding (λ max =222nm, 268nm,  ). The hyperchromism along with substantial blue shift for complexes 1 and 2 suggests an active interaction of thearomatic chromospheres with the DNA base pairs via partial intercalation, in addition to the electrostatic interactions of the copper(II) centers with the polyanionic phosphate backbone of the DNA. The observed spectral changes can also be associated with the strong binding interactions leading to the conformational changes of DNA . The intrinsic binding constant (K b) values of complexes 1 and 2 have been calculated by monitoring the changes in absorbance at 272 and 274nm, respectively, with increasing concentration of CT-DNA using the eqn. (1) where, [DNA] is the concentration of DNA, ε a is the ratio of the absorbance/[complex], ε f is the extinction coefficient for free metal complex, and ε b is the extinction coefficient for metal complex in the fully bound form.  (1)  [ DNA ] / (   ε   a   -   ε   f   ) = [ DNA ] / (   ε   b   -   ε   f   ) + 1 /   K   b   (   ε   b   -   ε   f   )

<ce:para id="p0110" view="all">In an attempt to further investigate the DNA binding property of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the competitive ethidium bromide (EthBr) displacement assay has been carried out in aqueous solution. This assay is based on the quenching of ethidium bromide fluorescence upon displacement of the DNA-bound ethidium bromide by the complexes. The emission intensity of a DNA-EthBr adduct can be quenched upon the addition of a second DNA binding molecule by either replacement of EthBr and/or by acceptance of the excited-state electron of the EthBr through a photoelectron transfer mechanism . The emission spectra of EthBr-DNA in the absence and presence of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>. The spectra show that there is a significant quenching of the emission intensity at 598<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon addition of increasing concentration of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> to CT-DNA/EthBr mixture indicating the competitive displacement of the bound ethidium bromide from the CT-DNA by complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Similarly, upon addition of increasing concentration of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> to CT-DNA/EthBr mixture, a significant quenching of the emission intensity at 600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm has been observed (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>). The above said emission band in the spectra of combined copper(II) complex-DNA system showed a reduction in the fluorescence intensity of around 50.05% and 26.31% for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively, revealing that the EthBr molecules are displaced from their DNA binding sites by the added complexes. These results also indicate that the complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> could interact to DNA through the groove binding mode releasing some EthBr molecules from the EthBr-DNA system. At a certain point, when small molecules bind independently to a set of equivalent sites on a macromolecule, some will be in bound condition and some will be in unbound condition. Therefore, the equilibrium between unbound and bound molecules is represented by the Scatchard equation:  log[(<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>

elements.clean_text: In an attempt to further investigate the DNA binding property of complexes 1 and 2, the competitive ethidium bromide (EthBr) displacement assay has been carried out in aqueous solution. This assay is based on the quenching of ethidium bromide fluorescence upon displacement of the DNA-bound ethidium bromide by the complexes. The emission intensity of a DNA-EthBr adduct can be quenched upon the addition of a second DNA binding molecule by either replacement of EthBr and/or by acceptance of the excited-state electron of the EthBr through a photoelectron transfer mechanism . The emission spectra of EthBr-DNA in the absence and presence of complex 1 are shown in  . The spectra show that there is a significant quenching of the emission intensity at 598nm upon addition of increasing concentration of complex 1 to CT-DNA/EthBr mixture indicating the competitive displacement of the bound ethidium bromide from the CT-DNA by complex 1. Similarly, upon addition of increasing concentration of complex 2 to CT-DNA/EthBr mixture, a significant quenching of the emission intensity at 600nm has been observed ( ). The above said emission band in the spectra of combined copper(II) complex-DNA system showed a reduction in the fluorescence intensity of around 50.05% and 26.31% for complexes 1 and 2, respectively, revealing that the EthBr molecules are displaced from their DNA binding sites by the added complexes. These results also indicate that the complexes 1 and 2 could interact to DNA through the groove binding mode releasing some EthBr molecules from the EthBr-DNA system. At a certain point, when small molecules bind independently to a set of equivalent sites on a macromolecule, some will be in bound condition and some will be in unbound condition. Therefore, the equilibrium between unbound and bound molecules is represented by the Scatchard equation:  log[(I 0 - I)/I]=log[K]+ n log[Q]; where K and n are the binding constant and the number of binding sites, respectively, I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities in the absence and presence of the quencher, respectively. Thus, the plots of log[(I 0 - I)/I] versus log[Q] () can be used to find the binding constant values which are evaluated to be (4.12±0.24)×104 M-1 and (3.16±0.22)×104 M-1 for complexes 1 and 2, respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0115" view="all">From the binding constant values obtained from UV–Vis and fluorescence titration experiments, it can be suggested that both complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> interact comparably with CT-DNA under the experimental binding conditions. The small difference in binding strength between the complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is most possibly due to the difference in the coordination geometry around the copper centers. The presence of the octahedral geometry around each copper center from where the loosely bound apical exogeneous water molecule can easily be eliminated, facilitates the formation of the complex/DNA adduct during the interaction of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with CT-DNA compared to that in case of a square pyramidal, trigonal bipyramidal and octahedral geometry around three copper centers in complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The calculated binding constant values are lower than that for the classical intercalator (ethidium bromide-DNA, 1.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) . The values rather suggest that the complexes bind with DNA in solution <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> electrostatic attraction or through coordination binding.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: From the binding constant values obtained from UV-Vis and fluorescence titration experiments, it can be suggested that both complexes 1 and 2 interact comparably with CT-DNA under the experimental binding conditions. The small difference in binding strength between the complexes 1 and 2 is most possibly due to the difference in the coordination geometry around the copper centers. The presence of the octahedral geometry around each copper center from where the loosely bound apical exogeneous water molecule can easily be eliminated, facilitates the formation of the complex/DNA adduct during the interaction of complex 1 with CT-DNA compared to that in case of a square pyramidal, trigonal bipyramidal and octahedral geometry around three copper centers in complex 2. The calculated binding constant values are lower than that for the classical intercalator (ethidium bromide-DNA, 1.4×106 M-1) . The values rather suggest that the complexes bind with DNA in solution via electrostatic attraction or through coordination binding.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0120" view="all">The contribution of the electrostatic attraction in the binding events of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with DNA was examined by adding the varying concentrations of NaCl in the range of 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup> to 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M to the reaction medium and running the UV–Vis titration spectra. The observed UV–Vis titration spectra () remain identical and clearly show no significant changes in the absorption intensities upon increase in the ionic strength of the solution. No significant change in the absorption intensities in the presence of varying concentrations of NaCl excludes the possibility of electrostatic attraction between the complexes and DNA. Therefore, from the binding constant values obtained it can be suggested that the complexes are weakly reacting/interacting with the DNA through coordination binding, which is in accordance with the observation noted in the theoretical calculations for the Fukui functions at the metal sites and HOMOs and LUMOs in complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The weak binding interaction of the complexes with DNA is most possibly due to the anionic nature of the complexes. The observed binding constant values are comparable to that of some copper(II) clusters reported in the literature .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The contribution of the electrostatic attraction in the binding events of complexes 1 and 2 with DNA was examined by adding the varying concentrations of NaCl in the range of 1×10-4 to 1×10-2 M to the reaction medium and running the UV-Vis titration spectra. The observed UV-Vis titration spectra () remain identical and clearly show no significant changes in the absorption intensities upon increase in the ionic strength of the solution. No significant change in the absorption intensities in the presence of varying concentrations of NaCl excludes the possibility of electrostatic attraction between the complexes and DNA. Therefore, from the binding constant values obtained it can be suggested that the complexes are weakly reacting/interacting with the DNA through coordination binding, which is in accordance with the observation noted in the theoretical calculations for the Fukui functions at the metal sites and HOMOs and LUMOs in complexes 1 and 2. The weak binding interaction of the complexes with DNA is most possibly due to the anionic nature of the complexes. The observed binding constant values are comparable to that of some copper(II) clusters reported in the literature .

<ce:section-title id="st100">Theoretical calculations</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0125" view="all">Theoretical calculations have been conducted to get a better understanding about the binding process of DNA with complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Calculations have been performed on the anionic species [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(cbal)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>1m</ce:bold>) and [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(cbal)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>2m</ce:bold>) of the representative complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and on the corresponding one-electron reduced analogues <ce:bold>1m</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and <ce:bold>2m</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> at the B3LYP level using the Gaussian 03 software package. The structures of both <ce:bold>1m</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2m</ce:bold> show the doublet (<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2) state, with optimized structural parameters fully consistent with crystallographic data. The one-electron-reduced species of both <ce:bold>1m</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and <ce:bold>2m</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> display a closed-shell singlet state (S<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0). The condensed Fukui function (<ce:italic>f</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">k</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>) values at the copper centers of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0015"></ce:float-anchor>. In complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the Fukui function values of all the copper centers are same in magnitude and thereby it is presumed that DNA binds as nucleophile to the three copper centers with equal probability. In complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the Fukui function values of all the copper centers are fairly close in magnitude and thereby it can be anticipated that DNA may interact with the three copper centers with more or less equal probability. The small difference in the Fukui function values at the copper sites is most likely due to the different coordination geometry around the three copper centers in complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. In <ce:bold>1m</ce:bold>, the HOMO and LUMOs are spread on and around the three copper centers indicating the involvement of all the copper centers in the binding process with DNA. In one-electron reduced analogue <ce:bold>1m</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, the HOMO and LUMOs are mostly located on the three copper centers (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0045"></ce:float-anchor>(a) and (b)). This is in accordance with the results observed in Fukui function calculations. Whereas, the HOMO in <ce:bold>2m</ce:bold> is spread on and around the three copper centers, the LUMO is mostly located on one copper center having the distorted square pyramidal geometry. In one-electron reduced analogue <ce:bold>2m</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, the HOMO and LUMOs are spread on and around the three copper centers ((c) and (d)), indicating the more involvement of one copper center and less involvement of other two copper centers in the binding process with DNA. Again, this is in accordance with the findings observed in Fukui function calculations. In general, copper(II) ion is known as fluorescence quencher. Recently, it has also been observed in the literature that the fluorescence emission of DNA and other substrates have significantly been quenched due to the binding with copper(II) ions . Therefore, theoretical calculations strongly suggest that the binding of DNA with complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> occurs more possibly through the copper centers which have been further supported by the fluorescence titration experiments having the significant quenching effect.</ce:para>

Theoretical calculations

Theoretical calculations have been conducted to get a better understanding about the binding process of DNA with complexes 1 and 2. Calculations have been performed on the anionic species [Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)3]- (1m) and [Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)]- (2m) of the representative complexes 1 and 2 and on the corresponding one-electron reduced analogues 1m - and 2m - at the B3LYP level using the Gaussian 03 software package. The structures of both 1m and 2m show the doublet (S =1/2) state, with optimized structural parameters fully consistent with crystallographic data. The one-electron-reduced species of both 1m - and 2m - display a closed-shell singlet state (S=0). The condensed Fukui function (f k +) values at the copper centers of complexes 1 and 2 are shown in  . In complex 1, the Fukui function values of all the copper centers are same in magnitude and thereby it is presumed that DNA binds as nucleophile to the three copper centers with equal probability. In complex 2, the Fukui function values of all the copper centers are fairly close in magnitude and thereby it can be anticipated that DNA may interact with the three copper centers with more or less equal probability. The small difference in the Fukui function values at the copper sites is most likely due to the different coordination geometry around the three copper centers in complex 2. In 1m, the HOMO and LUMOs are spread on and around the three copper centers indicating the involvement of all the copper centers in the binding process with DNA. In one-electron reduced analogue 1m -, the HOMO and LUMOs are mostly located on the three copper centers ( (a) and (b)). This is in accordance with the results observed in Fukui function calculations. Whereas, the HOMO in 2m is spread on and around the three copper centers, the LUMO is mostly located on one copper center having the distorted square pyramidal geometry. In one-electron reduced analogue 2m -, the HOMO and LUMOs are spread on and around the three copper centers ((c) and (d)), indicating the more involvement of one copper center and less involvement of other two copper centers in the binding process with DNA. Again, this is in accordance with the findings observed in Fukui function calculations. In general, copper(II) ion is known as fluorescence quencher. Recently, it has also been observed in the literature that the fluorescence emission of DNA and other substrates have significantly been quenched due to the binding with copper(II) ions . Therefore, theoretical calculations strongly suggest that the binding of DNA with complexes 1 and 2 occurs more possibly through the copper centers which have been further supported by the fluorescence titration experiments having the significant quenching effect.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st105">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0130" view="all">Water soluble multi-copper complexes have become a promising class of coordination compounds in which variation of the metal salts, ligands, counter ions or experimental conditions lead to a variety of structural motifs. The in-depth study on <ce:italic>in vitro</ce:italic> models of quantitative assay for developing target specific drug design based on structure–activity relationship has also become a prevalent theme in the biological processes. This has prompted our interest to synthesize and characterize new water soluble trinuclear copper(II) complexes containing a partial cubane [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] core with an unsymmetrical amino dicarboxylic ligand. The X-ray crystal structure analyses reveal that the three copper centers in the trinuclear unit of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are at the corners of an equilateral triangle with 3.202(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å edge length. On the other hand, the three copper centers in complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> form a scalene triangle with edges at 3.115(2), 3.174(3) and 3.204(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The complexes show not only stability but also reactions/interactions with CT-DNA in aqueous solution at physiological pH. The findings of the current study will contribute towards designing the water soluble new polynuclear transition metal complexes as potential binding agents to different biological macromolecules and subsequent metal-based pharmaceuticals.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Water soluble multi-copper complexes have become a promising class of coordination compounds in which variation of the metal salts, ligands, counter ions or experimental conditions lead to a variety of structural motifs. The in-depth study on in vitro models of quantitative assay for developing target specific drug design based on structure-activity relationship has also become a prevalent theme in the biological processes. This has prompted our interest to synthesize and characterize new water soluble trinuclear copper(II) complexes containing a partial cubane [Cu3O4] core with an unsymmetrical amino dicarboxylic ligand. The X-ray crystal structure analyses reveal that the three copper centers in the trinuclear unit of complex 1 are at the corners of an equilateral triangle with 3.202(2)Å edge length. On the other hand, the three copper centers in complex 2 form a scalene triangle with edges at 3.115(2), 3.174(3) and 3.204(3)Å. The complexes show not only stability but also reactions/interactions with CT-DNA in aqueous solution at physiological pH. The findings of the current study will contribute towards designing the water soluble new polynuclear transition metal complexes as potential binding agents to different biological macromolecules and subsequent metal-based pharmaceuticals.

<ce:bold>·</ce:bold>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and NaOH in 1:1:2 molar ratio in methanol at room temperature in air afforded a blue trinuclear copper(II) complex, [Na<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(cbal)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0050"></ce:float-anchor>). Similarly, the reaction of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>cbal with Cu(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>·</ce:bold>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in 1:1:2 molar ratio in methanol at ambient temperature in air yielded a blue trinuclear copper(II) complex, [K(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(cbal)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·3.75H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (). The molecular structures of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have been established using different analytical techniques such as elemental analysis, FTIR, UV–Vis, mass spectrometry and single crystal X-ray crystallography. The room temperature magnetic moment values per copper for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are 1.72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf> and 1.70<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf>, respectively, indicating the presence of one unpaired electron in each copper(II) ion.</ce:para>

Synthesis of N-(2-carboxybenzomethyl)-β-alanine, H2cbal

The ligand H2cbal was synthesized according to our previously published procedure . Yield: 8.5g (76%). Anal. Calcd. for C11H13NO4: C, 59.19; H, 5.87; N, 6.27. Found: C, 59.10; H, 5.92; N, 6.18%. FTIR (cm-1): ν =3427(b), 2967(b), 1698(s), 1597(s), 1454(s), 1392(s), 1340(s), 1242(s), 1175(s), 1057(s), 936(s), 837(s), 762(s), 718(s). 13C NMR for the sodium salt of the compound (100MHz, D2O, room temperature, δ): 180.03, 177.16, 138.97, 132.84, 130.48, 129.63, 128.26, 128.14, 50.57, 44.38, 35.55.

Synthesis of [Na6(H3O)4][Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)3]4(ClO4)6⋅3H2O (1)

A methanol (10ml) solution of Cu(ClO4)2 ⋅6H2O (0.415g, 1.12mmol) was added to a solution of H2cbal (0.250g, 1.12mmol) and NaOH (0.089g, 2.24mmol) in methanol (10ml) with magnetic stirring during a period of 15min. The reaction mixture was stirred for 1h resulting in a blue solution. The solution was filtered to discard any insoluble precipitate. The solvent was evaporated in air from the clear filtrate. The blue compound was isolated by filtration through a glass frit and washed with methanol and hexane and finally dried in vacuo over P4O10. Yield: 0.362g (85%). Anal. Calcd. for C132H172N12O92Cl6Na6Cu12 (1-3H2O): C, 35.14; H, 3.84; N, 3.73; Cu, 16.90. Found: C, 35.31; H, 3.67; N, 3.85; Cu, 16.75. FTIR (cm-1): ν =3422(b), 1607(s), 1593(s), 1569(s), 1451(s), 1372(s), 1202(s), 1140(s), 1087(s), 951(s), 897(s), 849(s), 764(s), 626(s). UV-Vis spectra: λ max (ε, lmol-1 cm-1) (H2O solution): 705 (231), 272 (7955), 228 (27523). Magnetic moment, μ eff (tot.): 2.97μB; μ eff/Cu: 1.72μB. Mass spectrum (ESI): m/z 877 (M - ={[Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-O)]+Li}-), 855 (M - ={[Cu3(cbal)3}-).

Synthesis of [K(H2O)2][Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)]⋅3.75H2O (2)

A methanol (10ml) solution of Cu(ClO4)2 ⋅6H2O (0.415g, 1.12mmol) was added to a solution of H2cbal (0.250g, 1.12mmol) and K2CO3 (0.309g, 2.24mmol) in methanol (10ml) with magnetic stirring during a period of 15min. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1h resulting in a blue solution. The solution was filtered to discard any insoluble precipitate. The solvent was evaporated in air from the clear filtrate. The blue compound was separated by filtration through a glass frit and washed with methanol and hexane and finally dried in vacuo over P4O10. Yield: 0.311g (90%). Anal. Calcd. for C33H40N3O16KCu3 (2-3.75H2O): C, 41.10; H, 4.18; N, 4.36; Cu, 19.77. Found: C, 41.35; H, 3.98; N, 4.57; Cu, 20.01. FTIR (KBr, cm-1): ν =3422(b), 1586(s), 1560(s), 1452(s), 1388(s), 1110(s), 1093(b), 947(s), 860(s), 763(s), 629(s). UV-Vis spectra: λ max (ε, lmol-1 cm-1) (H2O solution)=719 (86), 274 (2074), 225 (6771). Magnetic moment, μ eff (tot.): 2.94μB; μ eff/Cu: 1.70μB. Mass spectrum (ESI): m/z 927 (M - ={[Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-O)(H2O)(CH3OH)]+Li}-), 895 (M - ={[Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-O)(H2O)]+Li}-), 877 (M - ={[Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-O)]+Li}-), 855 (M - ={[Cu3(cbal)3}-).

The reaction of H2cbal with Cu(ClO4)2 ⋅6H2O and NaOH in 1:1:2 molar ratio in methanol at room temperature in air afforded a blue trinuclear copper(II) complex, [Na6(H3O)4][Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)3]4(ClO4)6⋅3H2O (1) ( ). Similarly, the reaction of H2cbal with Cu(ClO4)2 ⋅6H2O and K2CO3 in 1:1:2 molar ratio in methanol at ambient temperature in air yielded a blue trinuclear copper(II) complex, [K(H2O)2][Cu3(cbal)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)]⋅3.75H2O (2) (). The molecular structures of complexes 1 and 2 have been established using different analytical techniques such as elemental analysis, FTIR, UV-Vis, mass spectrometry and single crystal X-ray crystallography. The room temperature magnetic moment values per copper for complexes 1 and 2 are 1.72μB and 1.70μB, respectively, indicating the presence of one unpaired electron in each copper(II) ion.

</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">A structural view of the trinuclear unit of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with the atom numbering scheme is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>. The complex crystallizes in the hexagonal <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>6<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>m</ce:italic> space group with the refined formula [Na<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(cbal)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). In the unit cell four anionic [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(cbal)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> trinuclear units, six Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> and six ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> counter ions along with three water molecules of crystallization and additionally, to balance the total charge, four hydronium ions (formally O11 or O11B and O12) are present. The anionic cluster is constituted by three [Cu(cbal)] subunits in which each copper(II) ion is coordinated to a deprotonated tridentate ligand, cbal<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>. The [Cu(cbal)] subunits are held together by two distinct bridging systems: (i) one μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-hydroxo group (O5) which is coordinated to each of the three copper centers  and (ii) the three bridging aliphatic carboxylate oxygen atoms, each coming from different ligand unit. The resulting trinuclear species can be viewed as either a partial cubane or a cubane with one missing corner of the [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] core. In the trinuclear unit, the three copper(II) ions assemble at the corners of an equilateral triangle with ∼3.202(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å edges (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). Each copper(II) ion is in a Jahn–Teller distorted octahedral geometry with the bridging aliphatic carboxylate oxygen of the ligand and an exogenous H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecule occupying the elongated axial positions. While the square base of the octahedral geometry around each copper(II) center is defined by the O1, N1, O3′ and O5 atoms, the axial positions are taken by O3 and O10 atoms. The average Cu–O(bridging hydroxo) and Cu–O(bridging carboxylate) bond distances are 2.017 and 2.137<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. The Cu–O(hydroxo)–Cu and Cu–O(carboxylate)–Cu bridging angles are 105.1(2)° and 96.77(18)°, respectively. The μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-O5 atom is located at 0.807<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å above the plane defined by the three copper(II) ions. This induces a relatively bigger Cu–O(hydroxo)–Cu bridging bond angle of 105.1(2)° on the structure when compared to the smaller Cu–O(carboxylate)–Cu bridging angle of 96.77(18)°. The observed Cu-<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>-<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>-Cu inter-metallic distance at 3.202(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å in the complex is comparable to the values reported in the literature . The crystal structure of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> features several modes of carboxylate binding involved in a 3D coordination network in which the trinuclear Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> units are inter-linked through the Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ions (). The plentiful hydrogen bonding interactions among the coordinated water molecules and carboxylate oxygen atoms of the ligand contribute towards the stabilization of the crystal lattice.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st085">Description of X-ray crystal structure of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">A structural view of the trinuclear body of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with the atom numbering scheme is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>. The complex crystallizes in the monoclinic <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> space group with the refined formula [K(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(cbal)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·3.75H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. Unlike to complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, each metal center of the Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> unit poses different coordination geometries. The coordination geometry around the Cu1, Cu2 and Cu3 centers is best described as distorted octahedral, square pyramidal and trigonal bipyramidal geometry, respectively. While the square base of the octahedral geometry around the Cu1 center is defined by the O1, O14, O3 and N1 atoms, the axial positions are occupied by the O11 and O13 atoms. The square base of the square pyramidal geometry around the Cu2 center is described by the O5, O14, O7 and N2 atoms, whereas the axial position is occupied by the O3 atom. The trigonal bipyramidal geometry around Cu3 center is defined by the O5, O11 and O7 atoms at the equatorial position, and N3 and O14 atoms at the axial position. The coordination environment of the counter cation K<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> is best described by the distorted octahedral geometry, with four carboxylate and two water oxygens. The Cu1–O11 bond distance of 2.377(7)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å is slightly longer when compared to the 2.217(6) and 2.233(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å values for Cu2–O3 and Cu3–O7, respectively. The Cu–O(bridging carboxylate)–Cu bond angles are 97.6(2)°, 96.5(3)° and 94.2(3)° for Cu1–O3–Cu2, Cu2–O7–Cu3 and Cu3–O11–Cu1, respectively. The Cu1–O14 and Cu2–O14 bond length values between the copper(II) ions and the central μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH oxygen atom are almost identical at 2.069(6) and 2.002(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively, while the Cu3–O14 distance is 1.966(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-O14 atom is located at 0.842<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å above the plane defined by the three copper(II) ions. This opens the Cu–O<ce:inf loc="post">hydroxo</ce:inf>–Cu bond angle to an average value of 103.69°. Unlike to complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> triangle in complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is not equilateral as the Cu-<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>-<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>-Cu edges are at 3.115(2), 3.174(3) and 3.204(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å distances (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). Again, the average Cu-<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>-<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>-Cu separation of 3.164<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å is comparable to the values reported in the literature for similar complexes . Similar to complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the crystal structure of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> displays a 3D coordination network in which the trinuclear Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> units are connected to each other through K<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ions (). The complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> also shows an intricate hydrogen bonding among the coordinated water molecule, secondary amine and carboxylate groups of the ligand, contributing to the stabilization of the crystal structure.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st090">Solution UV–Vis and MS studies</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">The solution behavior of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was analyzed using UV–Vis and mass spectrometric techniques. UV–Vis spectra were obtained on aqueous solutions (pH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>∼<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7.5) of the complexes. The spectrum of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displays a broad absorption band at 705<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>ε</ce:italic>, 231<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>l<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) due to the d-d transition. The spectrum also shows two distinct metal ion bound ligand-based π<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> transitions at 272<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>ε</ce:italic>, 7955<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>l<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) and 228<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>ε</ce:italic>, 27<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>523<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>l<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>). Similarly, the spectrum of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows a broad absorption band at 719<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>ε</ce:italic>, 86<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>l<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) due to the d-d transition. <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) and 225<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>ε</ce:italic>, 6771<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>l<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>). No significant changes were observed in UV–Vis spectra when complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were measured in aqueous solutions (pH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>∼<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7.5) after ∼24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. The representative UV–Vis spectra for complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are shown in the .
